content: Bacteria play a crucial role in the human gut microbiome by facilitating the digestion and absorption of nutrients from food, producing vitamins, regulating the immune system, and protecting against harmful pathogens. They break down complex carbohydrates and fibers that cannot be digested by the human body, producing short-chain fatty acids that provide energy to colon cells and regulate glucose metabolism. Bacteria also produce important vitamins such as vitamin K and vitamin B12. Additionally, they have a key role in regulating the immune response, promoting the development of intestinal tissue and protecting against inflammation, and infections caused by harmful bacteria, viruses or other pathogens.
